data.text:
East 96th Street, west from First Ave. Note the Second and Third Ave. Elevated Lines upon their respective thoroughfares. Partially seen on the right is the abandoned car barn of the Second Ave. Railroad

Jamaica Ave., north side, east from 169th Street, showing in a set of two views in the foreground the home of G. Sayres in 1873; beyond it is that of Geo. Dawson.  A private Sanitarium occupied the house in the foreground in 1913.  It was demolished in August 1925.  On the site now are a group of taxpayers.

May 1923.
View 2: April 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Central Park: A set of 2 views northward across the Sailboat (also hnown as the Conservatory) Lake and showing buildings lining the eastern confine of the Park; Fifth Ave. Upon the latter, they progress northward from East 75th Street which appears on the right. The Synagogue shown is at the S.E. corner of East 76th Street and the Avenue.
May 2, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

data.text:
Canal Street, north side, west from Hudson (right) to Renwick (left) Streets. The photographer is viewing northwestward and includes at the right an extensive view up Hudson Street. Views 2 and 3 are of the same locale,though the latter veers eastward to show the westerly portion of the Holland Tunnel Plaza. The entrance to same adjoins the Board of Transportation Building, (Chevrolet sign). This structure occupies the entire easterly frontage of Hudson Street from Broome to Dominick Streets.
View 1: June 3, 1933
Views 2-3 July 26, 1935
P . L. Sperr

West 48th Street, north side, east from (No. 163, left) Seventh Ave., showing, the 48th Street Theatre occupying Nos. 159-155. On the right of set two appears the Sixth Ave. Elevated. These four pictures comprise two sets,of a negative and
a positive.

32nd Avenue, north side, at 103rd Street, viewing east across the latter. At the N.W. corner is the Union Evangelical Lutheran Church. October 17, 1935. P. L. Sperr.

Kosciuszko Bridge: A view across the area in Brooklyn where the new Kosciuszko Bridge will be thrown across Newtown Creek, linking Meeker Avenue in Brooklyn and Laurel Hill Boulevard in
Queens.
View 2 shows the $6,000,000 high-level span when completed, seen from Brooklyn. The bridge was formally named for the Polish patriot Thaddeus Kosciuszko by Mayor LaGuardia on September 22, 1940. For additional data see 'The New York Times," September 23,
1940.
View 1: August 13, 1938
View 2: August 22, 1939
P. L. Sperr
3) A more distant view of the bridge, seen from the Greenpoint
Avenue Bridge over New-town Creek.
P.L.Sperr  July 25, 1939

data.text: Madison Avenue, west side, from 27th to 28th Streets, showing the Mott Memorial Library, a free medical library, at 64 Madison Avenue (the 3-story building). The building on the northwest corner of 27th Street is the Hotel Madison. Next come the Mott Memorial and the Columbus Apartments, both of which will be demolished about 1917 to make room for a wing of the Prince George Hotel. Above them are shown 72-76 Madison Avenue, two newly built office buildings. 1911.

Essex Street, east side, from 126, south of Rivington Street.

(1)
Central Park: The Mall, crowd with roller skaters. During this and the following year, this sport, always more or less popular, suddenly became a craze; young, middle aged, and old, children and adults all took to roller skates. The Mall and the Central Park walks, together with the east sidewalk of Central Park West, were favorite locations, but by no means the only ones.
May 15, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)

data.text:
Forty-fifth Ave. (formerly Forest Ave., also Whittier Street), at the N.W. corner of Parsons Boulevard, showing the Flushing Hospital.  This structure does not appear in the 1928 Queens Atlas. It was demolished and replaced by a modern two, three and five story structure. The hospital no longer faces on Forest Ave. as this one does but on Parsons Boulevard. The only portion of the original structure is the brick building seen in the background

About 1909.

data.folder: Christopher Street - Waverly Place., Manhattan, NY

data.text:
243 E. 34th Street, adjoining the N. W. corner of Second Avenue, showing the "Civic Club." This structure was erected around 1900 by Norman Goddard as a Republican
Clubhouse.
No. 1 October 16, 1938
George v. Chinn
P. L. Sperr  No. 2 May 226, 1939

50th Avenue, west from 21st Street. Cleared area on the left was later constructed into a wide concrete approach to the Rueens-Midtown Tunnel. In the right background is the Empire State Building in Manhattan.
November 18, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority

(1)
609, 6ll-623 West 43rd Street, north side, between Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues, showing the offices and printing plant
of 'The Gentlewoman."
May 29, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, four years later, seen across the clearing between 42nd and 43rd Streets; the view is northeast instead of northWest.
March 20, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

data.folder: 47th Street (East) #231 - Second Avenue looking east, Manhattan, NY

data.text:
Union Turnpike, north side, between 135th and Main Streets, showing two views of new houses, which were constructed on former farmland on either side of Vleigh Place, formerly The Head of Vleigh Road. View 1 shows an area of small individual houses between 135th Street and Vleigh Place; View 2, an apartment house between VLeigh Place and Main Street. The views are northwestward towards the World's Fair Grounds in Flushing Meadow Park (Ferisphere & Trylon), across Grand Central Parkway in the depression behind the field; seen from 82nd and Coolidge Avenues.

August 11, 1940.
